It's not about appeal, it's about defining what the party stands for.
Reagan defined the GOP in terms of lower taxes (supply side), fear of government, hawkish foreign policy and Christian religion.
FDR defined the Democratic party as "new deal" or generally government safety net programs and concern for the poor, government choreography of economy (fed), etc.
Obama while a fine president did not change or redefine the Democratic party, just furthered its goals that had already been established.

Uhhh, that's where we got the current situation. Gaza was part of Egypt, West Bank was part of Jordan and Golan was part of Syria.
Israel took them during a defensive war (anyone who tells you that because Israel was the aggressor in 67 is ignorant (willfully or otherwise) of the context of that war), until that point there were no calls for an independent Palestinian nation (outside of getting rid of Israel), and there were certainly no calls for Jordan and Egypt to end their "occupation" of those territories, including Jerusalem (which was supposed to be a neutral, internationally administered territory for everyone, until Jordan unilaterally conquered it in 48 and kicked out the Jews).
So essentially these peoples did have their own "countries", which were conquered defensively after being attacked. But here we are. So I don't think that's the goal.

C) they usually are in very cramped and tiny quarters
D) charity and gov housing subsidies.

WRITING.TEXT:
Not exactly with that phrasing, but I'm not a movie person. I usually watch movies as a way to zone out when stressed out tired. Mild entertainment, and not too emotionally or intellectually invested in the movie. I only really watch, maybe once a month, at most.
Therefore I don't watch many dramas or thrillers etc. Just stupid comedies and some action films and family animation films.
It doesn't mean I don't appreciate those other films, or enjoy them, when I have the time or emotional space to give them.
It's just not a high priority for me, and not how I choose to watch.
Therefore, if recommended a "serious" or "artsy" film, I won't get around to it for a very long time, and if I boiled the reason down, it would be that I have to pay attention to it, and I don't feel like paying attention.

Everyone seems to be talking about the Suzuki method, 10000 hours of practice, etc.
That's not the question here. The question is why, within and among those who practice, there are some who outshine their peers, and also some who seem to have a head start. Clearly, Mozart, who began performing at 3 had innate talent - after all, he wasn't even alive for 10000 hours yet.
Starting with the latter, it might be that some people have better hearing (more in tune, including up to pitch perfect hearing), some have better fine motor skills (pick up intricate finger motions and delicate dexterity), some have better rythm or math skills to understand the underlying scale and complexity of music, with, when combined with a more creative mind and problem solving skills, can create music that is great.
With sports, obviously, tall people have more "innate" basketball talent; people with enlarged hearts can perform better at stamina and aerobic sports (marathon; racing; swimming). People talk about Phelps odd body, which is uniquely suited to swimming fast (long arms, wide hands and toes, tapered torso, etc)
So there are physical aspects to becoming great at something. With some sports, like football, Tom Brady is known to be great because he understands the psychology of football, which means he can exploit certain things better. This means, being intelligent and creative makes for a better or more talented player, not just body. If course, some people are naturally stronger, faster and more fit, which will definitely help with sports.
This is why, it's not just practice, people at professional level of sports, music, art etc all practice for thousands of hours, yet there is only one Gretzky, Jordan, Mozart, Picasso etc.

Mozart wasn't even alive for 10000 hours before he was known as a musical prodigy and composing music. Was he not talented?
I guess the question op is asking semantics, but what makes some people savant?
Clearly, in professional sports, they are all putting in thousands of hours of practice, and besides for physical uniqueness (like Lance Armstrong and Michael Phelps), there is a reason Michael Jordan and Wayne Gretzky dominate their sports, and it's not just the practice

No. The remaking of Hebrew is only in context of natively speaking and in common parlance of a nation.
Hebrew was regularly spoken and studied and used in prayer from ancient times through today. Most jewish scholars published, and they are almist all in Hebrew.
The Mishna, rashi, tosafot, rishonim, tur and shulchan aruch, and even all the writings of the maharal himself was written in Hebrew.
The majority of prayers, which are about 60 pages recited by jewish people daily is in Hebrew.
If anything, Aramaic is less commonly used because of how few books and prayers were written in it, even though it wasn't entirely uncommon, as mentioned above.
This is why Kabbalah is written in Aramaic, because it's slightly less accessible than Hebrew to the common folk. Also, according to jewish lore, angels can't understand Aramaic, so to bypass angels, and go directly to god, they believe in using Aramaic. Hence the use of Aramaic in kabbalist magic

No. The Zohar was written in Aramaic. Jews have always spoken and studied in local languages, but also in Hebrew, Yiddish and Aramaic. The Talmud is in Aramaic, as are other texts and liturgies.
So, basically all Jews everywhere were familar with the language to some extent (kaddish, one of the most basic and famous prayers is in Aramaic). They would not have considered Aramaic to be foreign or exotic at all.
The Zohar is the seminal kabbalist text. Written in Spain (Moses de Leon or something) in Aramaic.

Maharal lived in Prague. Kabala is jewish mysticism. Maharal was a mystic. Jewish mystic writing is in Aramaic.

Very close. Any modern Hebrew speaker can pick up an ancient Hebrew text and read it fine. Some technical words would be different or semantically different. There was basically one grammar change to accommodate creation of new words (-on suffix to imply relation).
Ancient Israelites could drop in and read modern Hebrew, but many words would be new for new inventions and concepts.
All in all remarkably similar.

One thing that people seem to miss, and this goes for Giuliani and Gingrich, is that most cabinet and other high level positions rarely last as long as the administration.

Among the many reasons mentioned, they actually saw a big increase in implementation in passenger jets in 2002ish.
Reason being that there was a plane crash (shortly after 9/11) in Queens new York shortly after takeoff. It was determined that this incident was caused, in part, by excessive turbulence in the air from a jet that took off just before it.
Winglets were found to dramatically decrease turbulence caused by the close confluence of differently pressurized air at the wing tips. This would have prevented the crash, and it was found to increase flight efficiency and stability, etc.
Military planes have different mission requirements.
